briefdescription.para: Network buffer allocator callback.

detaileddescription.para: The allocator callback is called when net_buf_append_bytes needs to allocate a new net_buf.

parameterdescription.para: Affects the action taken should the net buf pool be empty. If K_NO_WAIT, then return immediately. If K_FOREVER, then wait as long as necessary. Otherwise, wait until the specified timeout.
The user data given in net_buf_append_bytes call.

simplesect.para: pointer to allocated net_buf or NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Initialize a net_buf_simple object.

detaileddescription.para: This needs to be called after creating a net_buf_simple object using the NET_BUF_SIMPLE macro.

briefdescription.para: Initialize a net_buf_simple object with data.

detaileddescription.para: Initialized buffer object with external data.

parameterdescription.para: Amount of data the pointed data buffer if able to fit.

briefdescription.para: Reset buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Reset buffer data so it can be reused for other purposes.
Clone buffer state, using the same data buffer.
Initializes a buffer to point to the same data as an existing buffer. Allows operations on the same data without altering the length and offset of the original.

briefdescription.para: Prepare data to be added at the end of the buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Increments the data length of a buffer to account for more data at the end.

parameterdescription.para: Number of bytes to increment the length with.

simplesect.para: The original tail of the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Copy given number of bytes from memory to the end of the buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Increments the data length of the buffer to account for more data at the end.

parameterdescription.para: Location of data to be added.
Length of data to be added

simplesect.para: The original tail of the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Add (8-bit) byte at the end of the buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Increments the data length of the buffer to account for more data at the end.

simplesect.para: Pointer to the value added

briefdescription.para: Add 16-bit value at the end of the buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Adds 16-bit value in little endian format at the end of buffer. Increments the data length of a buffer to account for more data at the end.

briefdescription.para: Remove data from the end of the buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Removes data from the end of the buffer by modifying the buffer length.

detaileddescription.para: Same idea as with net_buf_simple_remove_mem(), but a helper for operating on 8-bit values.

briefdescription.para: Get the tail pointer for a buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Get a pointer to the end of the data in a buffer.

simplesect.para: Tail pointer for the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Check buffer headroom.

detaileddescription.para: Check how much free space there is in the beginning of the buffer.
buf A valid pointer on a buffer

simplesect.para: Number of bytes available in the beginning of the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Check buffer tailroom.

detaileddescription.para: Check how much free space there is at the end of the buffer.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on a buffer

simplesect.para: Number of bytes available at the end of the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Check maximum net_buf_simple::len value.

detaileddescription.para: This value is depending on the number of bytes being reserved as headroom.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on a buffer

simplesect.para: Number of bytes usable behind the net_buf_simple::data pointer.

briefdescription.para: Save the parsing state of a buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Saves the parsing state of a buffer so it can be restored later.

parameterdescription.para: Buffer from which the state should be saved.

briefdescription.para: Restore the parsing state of a buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Restores the parsing state of a buffer from a state previously stored by net_buf_simple_save().

parameterdescription.para: Buffer to which the state should be restored.

briefdescription.para: Looks up a pool based on its ID.

simplesect.para: Pointer to pool.

briefdescription.para: Get a zero-based index for a buffer.

detaileddescription.para: This function will translate a buffer into a zero-based index, based on its placement in its buffer pool. This can be useful if you want to associate an external array of meta-data contexts with the buffers of a pool.

simplesect.para: Zero-based index for the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Allocate a new fixed buffer from a pool.

parameterdescription.para: Which pool to allocate the buffer from.

Affects the action taken should the pool be empty. If K_NO_WAIT, then return immediately. If K_FOREVER, then wait as long as necessary. Otherwise, wait until the specified timeout. Note that some types of data allocators do not support blocking (such as the HEAP type). In this case it's still possible for net_buf_alloc() to fail (return NULL) even if it was given K_FOREVER.

simplesect.para: New buffer or NULL if out of buffers.

parameterdescription.para: Which pool to allocate the buffer from.

Affects the action taken should the pool be empty. If K_NO_WAIT, then return immediately. If K_FOREVER, then wait as long as necessary. Otherwise, wait until the specified timeout. Note that some types of data allocators do not support blocking (such as the HEAP type). In this case it's still possible for net_buf_alloc() to fail (return NULL) even if it was given K_FOREVER.

simplesect.para: New buffer or NULL if out of buffers.

briefdescription.para: Allocate a new variable length buffer from a pool.

parameterdescription.para: Which pool to allocate the buffer from.
Amount of data the buffer must be able to fit.

Affects the action taken should the pool be empty. If K_NO_WAIT, then return immediately. If K_FOREVER, then wait as long as necessary. Otherwise, wait until the specified timeout. Note that some types of data allocators do not support blocking (such as the HEAP type). In this case it's still possible for net_buf_alloc() to fail (return NULL) even if it was given K_FOREVER.

simplesect.para: New buffer or NULL if out of buffers.

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_buf_pool *pool, void *data, size_t size, k_timeout_t timeout)
memberdef.name: net_buf_alloc_with_data

briefdescription.para: Allocate a new buffer from a pool but with external data pointer.

detaileddescription.para: Allocate a new buffer from a pool, where the data pointer comes from the user and not from the pool.

parameterdescription.para: Which pool to allocate the buffer from.
Amount of data the pointed data buffer if able to fit.

Affects the action taken should the pool be empty. If K_NO_WAIT, then return immediately. If K_FOREVER, then wait as long as necessary. Otherwise, wait until the specified timeout. Note that some types of data allocators do not support blocking (such as the HEAP type). In this case it's still possible for net_buf_alloc() to fail (return NULL) even if it was given K_FOREVER.

simplesect.para: New buffer or NULL if out of buffers.

briefdescription.para: Get a buffer from a FIFO.

detaileddescription.para: This function is NOT thread-safe if the buffers in the FIFO contain fragments.

parameterdescription.para: Which FIFO to take the buffer from.
Affects the action taken should the FIFO be empty. If K_NO_WAIT, then return immediately. If K_FOREVER, then wait as long as necessary. Otherwise, wait until the specified timeout.

simplesect.para: New buffer or NULL if the FIFO is empty.

briefdescription.para: Destroy buffer from custom destroy callback.

detaileddescription.para: This helper is only intended to be used from custom destroy callbacks. If no custom destroy callback is given to NET_BUF_POOL_*_DEFINE() then there is no need to use this API.

briefdescription.para: Reset buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Reset buffer data and flags so it can be reused for other purposes.

briefdescription.para: Initialize buffer with the given headroom.

detaileddescription.para: The buffer is not expected to contain any data when this API is called.

briefdescription.para: Put a buffer into a list.

detaileddescription.para: If the buffer contains follow-up fragments this function will take care of inserting them as well into the list.

parameterdescription.para: Which list to append the buffer to.

briefdescription.para: Get a buffer from a list.

detaileddescription.para: If the buffer had any fragments, these will automatically be recovered from the list as well and be placed to the buffer's fragment list.

parameterdescription.para: Which list to take the buffer from.

simplesect.para: New buffer or NULL if the FIFO is empty.

briefdescription.para: Put a buffer to the end of a FIFO.

detaileddescription.para: If the buffer contains follow-up fragments this function will take care of inserting them as well into the FIFO.

parameterdescription.para: Which FIFO to put the buffer to.

briefdescription.para: Decrements the reference count of a buffer.

detaileddescription.para: The buffer is put back into the pool if the reference count reaches zero.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on a buffer

briefdescription.para: Increment the reference count of a buffer.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on a buffer

simplesect.para: the buffer newly referenced

briefdescription.para: Clone buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Duplicate given buffer including any data and headers currently stored.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on a buffer
Affects the action taken should the pool be empty. If K_NO_WAIT, then return immediately. If K_FOREVER, then wait as long as necessary. Otherwise, wait until the specified timeout.

simplesect.para: Cloned buffer or NULL if out of buffers.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on a buffer

detaileddescription.para: Check how much free space there is at the end of the buffer.

simplesect.para: Number of bytes available at the end of the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Check buffer headroom.

detaileddescription.para: Check how much free space there is in the beginning of the buffer.
buf A valid pointer on a buffer

simplesect.para: Number of bytes available in the beginning of the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Check maximum net_buf::len value.

detaileddescription.para: This value is depending on the number of bytes being reserved as headroom.

parameterdescription.para: A valid pointer on a buffer

simplesect.para: Number of bytes usable behind the net_buf::data pointer.

briefdescription.para: Get the tail pointer for a buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Get a pointer to the end of the data in a buffer.

simplesect.para: Tail pointer for the buffer.

briefdescription.para: Find the last fragment in the fragment list.

simplesect.para: Pointer to last fragment in the list.

briefdescription.para: Insert a new fragment to a chain of bufs.

detaileddescription.para: Insert a new fragment into the buffer fragments list after the parent.
Note: This function takes ownership of the fragment reference so the caller is not required to unref.

briefdescription.para: Add a new fragment to the end of a chain of bufs.

detaileddescription.para: Append a new fragment into the buffer fragments list.
Note: This function takes ownership of the fragment reference so the caller is not required to unref.

simplesect.para: New head of the fragment chain. Either head (if head was non-NULL) or frag (if head was NULL).

briefdescription.para: Delete existing fragment from a chain of bufs.

parameterdescription.para: Parent buffer/fragment, or NULL if there is no parent.

simplesect.para: Pointer to the buffer following the fragment, or NULL if it had no further fragments.

memberdef.argsstring: (void *dst, size_t dst_len, struct net_buf *src, size_t offset, size_t len)
memberdef.name: net_buf_linearize

briefdescription.para: Copy bytes from net_buf chain starting at offset to linear buffer.

detaileddescription.para: Copy (extract) len bytes from src net_buf chain, starting from offset in it, to a linear buffer dst. Return number of bytes actually copied, which may be less than requested, if net_buf chain doesn't have enough data, or destination buffer is too small.

simplesect.para: number of bytes actually copied

memberdef.argsstring: (struct net_buf *buf, size_t len, const void *value, k_timeout_t timeout, net_buf_allocator_cb allocate_cb, void *user_data)
memberdef.name: net_buf_append_bytes

briefdescription.para: Append data to a list of net_buf.

detaileddescription.para: Append data to a net_buf. If there is not enough space in the net_buf then more net_buf will be added, unless there are no free net_buf and timeout occurs. If not allocator is provided it attempts to allocate from the same pool as the original buffer.

parameterdescription.para: Timeout is passed to the net_buf allocator callback.
When a new net_buf is required, use this callback.
A user data pointer to be supplied to the allocate_cb. This pointer is can be anything from a mem_pool or a net_pkt, the logic is left up to the allocate_cb function.

simplesect.para: Length of data actually added. This may be less than input length if other timeout than K_FOREVER was used, and there were no free fragments in a pool to accommodate all data.

briefdescription.para: Skip N number of bytes in a net_buf.

detaileddescription.para: Skip N number of bytes starting from fragment's offset. If the total length of data is placed in multiple fragments, this function will skip from all fragments until it reaches N number of bytes. Any fully skipped buffers are removed from the net_buf list.

parameterdescription.para: Total length of data to be skipped.

simplesect.para: Pointer to the fragment or NULL and pos is 0 after successful skip, NULL and pos is 0xffff otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Calculate amount of bytes stored in fragments.

detaileddescription.para: Calculates the total amount of data stored in the given buffer and the fragments linked to it.

simplesect.para: Number of bytes in the buffer and its fragments.

memberdef.name: NET_BUF_SIMPLE_DEFINE
memberdef.initializer: uint8_t net_buf_data_##_name[_size]; \ struct net_buf_simple _name = { \ .data = net_buf_data_##_name, \ .len = 0, \ .size = _size, \ .__buf = net_buf_data_##_name, \ }

briefdescription.para: Define a net_buf_simple stack variable.

detaileddescription.para: This is a helper macro which is used to define a net_buf_simple object on the stack.

parameterdescription.para: Maximum data storage for the buffer.

memberdef.name: NET_BUF_SIMPLE_DEFINE_STATIC
memberdef.initializer: static __noinit uint8_t net_buf_data_##_name[_size]; \ static struct net_buf_simple _name = { \ .data = net_buf_data_##_name, \ .len = 0, \ .size = _size, \ .__buf = net_buf_data_##_name, \ }

briefdescription.para: Define a static net_buf_simple variable.

detaileddescription.para: This is a helper macro which is used to define a static net_buf_simple object.

parameterdescription.para: Maximum data storage for the buffer.

memberdef.name: NET_BUF_SIMPLE

briefdescription.para: Define a net_buf_simple stack variable and get a pointer to it.

detaileddescription.para: This is a helper macro which is used to define a net_buf_simple object on the stack and the get a pointer to it as follows:
struct net_buf_simple *my_buf = NET_BUF_SIMPLE(10);
After creating the object it needs to be initialized by calling net_buf_simple_init().

parameterdescription.para: Maximum data storage for the buffer.

simplesect.para: Pointer to stack-allocated net_buf_simple object.

detaileddescription.para: Flag indicating that the buffer has associated fragments. Only used internally by the buffer handling code while the buffer is inside a FIFO, meaning this never needs to be explicitly set or unset by the net_buf API user. As long as the buffer is outside of a FIFO, i.e. in practice always for the user for this API, the buf->frags pointer should be used instead.

Flag indicating that the buffer's associated data pointer, points to externally allocated memory. Therefore once ref goes down to zero, the pointed data will not need to be deallocated. This never needs to be explicitly set or unet by the net_buf API user. Such net_buf is exclusively instantiated via net_buf_alloc_with_data() function. Reference count mechanism however will behave the same way, and ref count going to 0 will free the net_buf but no the data pointer in it.

briefdescription.para: Define a new pool for buffers using the heap for the data.

detaileddescription.para: Defines a net_buf_pool struct and the necessary memory storage (array of structs) for the needed amount of buffers. After this, the buffers can be accessed from the pool through net_buf_alloc. The pool is defined as a static variable, so if it needs to be exported outside the current module this needs to happen with the help of a separate pointer rather than an extern declaration.

The data payload of the buffers will be allocated from the heap using k_malloc, so CONFIG_HEAP_MEM_POOL_SIZE must be set to a positive value. This kind of pool does not support blocking on the data allocation, so the timeout passed to net_buf_alloc will be always treated as K_NO_WAIT when trying to allocate the data. This means that allocation failures, i.e. NULL returns, must always be handled cleanly.
If provided with a custom destroy callback, this callback is responsible for eventually calling net_buf_destroy() to complete the process of returning the buffer to the pool.

parameterdescription.para: Number of buffers in the pool.
User data space to reserve per buffer.
Optional destroy callback when buffer is freed.

memberdef.name: NET_BUF_POOL_FIXED_DEFINE
memberdef.initializer: _NET_BUF_ARRAY_DEFINE(_name, _count, _ud_size); \ static uint8_t __noinit net_buf_data_##_name[_count][_data_size]; \ static const struct net_buf_pool_fixed net_buf_fixed_##_name = { \ .data_size = _data_size, \ .data_pool = (uint8_t *)net_buf_data_##_name, \ }; \ static const struct net_buf_data_alloc net_buf_fixed_alloc_##_name = { \ .cb = &net_buf_fixed_cb, \ .alloc_data = (void *)&net_buf_fixed_##_name, \ }; \ static STRUCT_SECTION_ITERABLE(net_buf_pool, _name) = \ NET_BUF_POOL_INITIALIZER(_name, &net_buf_fixed_alloc_##_name, \ _net_buf_##_name, _count, _ud_size, \ _destroy)

briefdescription.para: Define a new pool for buffers based on fixed-size data.

detaileddescription.para: Defines a net_buf_pool struct and the necessary memory storage (array of structs) for the needed amount of buffers. After this, the buffers can be accessed from the pool through net_buf_alloc. The pool is defined as a static variable, so if it needs to be exported outside the current module this needs to happen with the help of a separate pointer rather than an extern declaration.

The data payload of the buffers will be allocated from a byte array of fixed sized chunks. This kind of pool does not support blocking on the data allocation, so the timeout passed to net_buf_alloc will be always treated as K_NO_WAIT when trying to allocate the data. This means that allocation failures, i.e. NULL returns, must always be handled cleanly.
If provided with a custom destroy callback, this callback is responsible for eventually calling net_buf_destroy() to complete the process of returning the buffer to the pool.

parameterdescription.para: Number of buffers in the pool.
User data space to reserve per buffer.
Optional destroy callback when buffer is freed.

memberdef.name: NET_BUF_POOL_VAR_DEFINE
memberdef.initializer: _NET_BUF_ARRAY_DEFINE(_name, _count, _ud_size); \ K_HEAP_DEFINE(net_buf_mem_pool_##_name, _data_size); \ static const struct net_buf_data_alloc net_buf_data_alloc_##_name = { \ .cb = &net_buf_var_cb, \ .alloc_data = &net_buf_mem_pool_##_name, \ }; \ static STRUCT_SECTION_ITERABLE(net_buf_pool, _name) = \ NET_BUF_POOL_INITIALIZER(_name, &net_buf_data_alloc_##_name, \ _net_buf_##_name, _count, _ud_size, \ _destroy)

briefdescription.para: Define a new pool for buffers with variable size payloads.

detaileddescription.para: Defines a net_buf_pool struct and the necessary memory storage (array of structs) for the needed amount of buffers. After this, the buffers can be accessed from the pool through net_buf_alloc. The pool is defined as a static variable, so if it needs to be exported outside the current module this needs to happen with the help of a separate pointer rather than an extern declaration.
The data payload of the buffers will be based on a memory pool from which variable size payloads may be allocated.
If provided with a custom destroy callback, this callback is responsible for eventually calling net_buf_destroy() to complete the process of returning the buffer to the pool.

parameterdescription.para: Number of buffers in the pool.
Total amount of memory available for data payloads.
User data space to reserve per buffer.
Optional destroy callback when buffer is freed.

briefdescription.para: Define a new pool for buffers.

detaileddescription.para: Defines a net_buf_pool struct and the necessary memory storage (array of structs) for the needed amount of buffers. After this,the buffers can be accessed from the pool through net_buf_alloc. The pool is defined as a static variable, so if it needs to be exported outside the current module this needs to happen with the help of a separate pointer rather than an extern declaration.
If provided with a custom destroy callback this callback is responsible for eventually calling net_buf_destroy() to complete the process of returning the buffer to the pool.

parameterdescription.para: Number of buffers in the pool.
Maximum data size for each buffer.
Amount of user data space to reserve.
Optional destroy callback when buffer is freed.

briefdescription.para: Network buffer library.
